editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msDesc.head: THOMAS AQUINAS, PIERRE D'AUVERGNE, THOMAS SUTTON; S. XIV in.

msItem.note: Fols. i-ii blank; on f. iiv is a title, s. xvii.

msItem.author: Thomas Aquinas
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Caelo et Mundo I-II
msItem.incipit: Sicut dicit philosophus primo Phisicorum tunc opinamur unumquodque scire
msItem.explicit: de stellis et in hoc terminatur sentencia secundi libri.
msItem.finalRubric: Finit liber iius a fratre Thoma de Aquino.

msItem.author: PETRUS DE ALVERNIA
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Caelo et Mundo III-IV
msItem.incipit: De primo quidem igitur celo. Cum philosophus compleuit considerationem de corporibus simplicibus
msItem.explicit: quorum conditor primus est Deus benedictus in s. s.
msItem.finalRubric: In hoc completur expositio magistri Petri de Aluernia.
msItem.note: Pr. Venice 1495 (GW2355); Glorieux, Théol. 210v; Lohr, pp. 337–8.

msItem.author: Thomas Aquinas
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Generatione et Corruptione
msItem.incipit: Sicut philosophus tradit in tertio de Anima sciencie secantur quemadmodum et res
msItem.explicit: et fiet totaliter aqua. Quoniam autem primum.
msItem.finalRubric: Hic terminatur expositio fratris Thome de Aquino et incipit expositio fratris Thome de Suthona.

msItem.author: THOMAS DE SUTTON OP
msItem.title: Supplementum super I-II de Generatione
msItem.incipit: Quoniam autem primum oportet &c. Postquam philosophus determinauit de generatione et corruptione in communi
msItem.explicit: a quo omnia participant esse Ipsi honor et gloria ...
msItem.note: The unique copy; ed. F. E. Kelley (Texte aus der mittelalterlichen Geisteswelt 6: Munich, 1976); Lohr, pp. 186–7; Kaeppeli 3867.

msItem.author: PETRUS DE ALVERNIA
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, Meteora
msItem.incipit: Philosophus in primo Phisicorum proponit innata ex certioribus et nocioribus nobis
msItem.explicit: a quo principaliter procedunt et diriguntur omnia Qui ...
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit sentencia magistri Petri de Auernia super libris Metherorum Aristotilis.
msItem.note: Pr. Salamanca 1497; Glorieux, Théol. 210g; Lohr, pp. 338–9.
Followed, in an anglicana hand, by a list of ‘Questiones mote super iiii Meteororum per P. Al.'

msItem.author: PETRUS DE ALVERNIA
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Somno et Vigilia
msItem.incipit: Secundum philosophum secundo Phisicorum Quecumque mouent mota sunt naturalis consideracionis
msItem.explicit: et a causa supernaturali Deo qui est benedictus in s. s.

msItem.author: PETRUS DE ALVERNIA
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Motu Animalium
msItem.incipit: Sicut innuit philosophus 3. Phisicorum uolentem considerare de natura
msItem.explicit: ergo dicendum est de generatione animalium.
msItem.note: Many copies, unpr.; Glorieux, Théol. 210e; Lohr, pp. 340–1.

msItem.author: PETRUS DE ALVERNIA
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Iuuentute et Senectute
msItem.incipit: Sicut dicit philosophus primo phisicorum innata est nobis uia ex nobis nocioribus

msItem.author: PETRUS DE ALVERNIA
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Respiratione
msItem.incipit: Animalium autem &c. Postquam philosophus declarauit qualiter fiat refrigeracio in plantis

msItem.author: PETRUS DE ALVERNIA
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Vita et Morte
msItem.incipit: Est quidem omnibus. Postquam philosophus determinauit de infrigidacione in animalibus
msItem.explicit: habent ad mortem et uitam fere.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit sentencia magistri Petri de Aluernia de morte et uita.
msItem.note: Pr. Padua 1493, &c.; Glorieux, Théol. 210p; Lohr, pp. 341–2.

msItem.author: Thomas Aquinas
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Sensu et Sensato
msItem.incipit: Sicut dicit philosophus in tercio de anima sicut separabiles sunt res a materia

msItem.author: Thomas Aquinas
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Memoria et Reminiscentia
msItem.incipit: Sicut dicit philosophus in vij. de historiis animalium natura ex inanimatis
msItem.explicit: in quomodo fiat et propter quam causam.

msItem.note: On f. 320, in an anglicana hand, is a summary of ARISTOTLE, Physica, bk. 1. On f. 321 is an informal table of contents; 321v blank.

supportDesc.extent:
323 leaves (ii + 321) 300 210
220 145
The edges retrimmed and spattered with red.
supportDesc.collation: A bifolium at each end, 1–712, 812(lacks 12), 9–1012, 114(3–4 canc.), 12–1912, 206, 21–812; framed catchwords.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with crayon in 2 cols of 45 lines.

decoDesc.decoNote: Parisian. Red and blue flourished initials with long extensions; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; red or blue paraphs; running heads in capitals of the colours; underlining in red.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii, sewn on five bands; formerly chained from the usual position. The outermost leaves were formerly pastedowns in an earlier binding. Near the foot of the early leaves is the mark of a chain-staple.

history.provenance: Bought for the College when Richard Billingham was subwarden, c. 1350 (Appendix B, no. 50), as was MS 273. On f. 320v ‘Liber scolarium de Merton ex empcione’. UO48. 6.
Inside the front board is a sheet of paper with an elaborate table of contents, s. xvii, and ‘Q. 1. 6. Art:’, canc. and replaced with ‘O. 1. 5 (CCLXXIV)’ in red; the College bookplate.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.

listBibl.bibl: Coxe, pp. 107–8; Powicke, no. 517; Dondaine & Shooner, no. 2150.
